{{Infobox sport overview | boxwidth = 250 | title = Lacrosse in Israel | image = | imagesize = | image_alt = | caption = | union = Israel Lacrosse Association | country = Israel | sport = Lacrosse | noncountry = | teamlabel1 = | nationalteam = [[Israel men's national lacrosse team|Men's national team]]
[[Israel women's national lacrosse team|Women's national team]] | teamlabel2 = | repteam = | nickname = | first = | registered = | clubs = | national_list = | intl_list = [[World Lacrosse Championship]]
[[Women's Lacrosse World Cup]]
[[World Indoor Lacrosse Championship]]
[[European Lacrosse Championships]] | match = | league = }} '''[[Lacrosse]] in [[Israel]]''' is a minor sport, with 700 players as of June 2015.[http://jewishtimes.com/38132/bridging-gaps-through-lacrosse/news/local-news/ Bridging Gaps Through Lacrosse] ==Israel Lacrosse Association== {{Infobox Sport governing body |assocname= Israel Lacrosse Association |sport= Lacrosse |founded = 2010 |aff = [[European Lacrosse Federation]] [[Federation of International Lacrosse]] |headquarters = [[Ashkelon]], [[Israel]] |founder = Scott Neiss |coach = [[William Beroza]] |GM = Howard Borkan |COO = David Lasday |url = www.lacrosse.co.il |countryflag= Israel |countryflag2= }} The '''Israel Lacrosse Association''' (ILA) is the official governing body of [[lacrosse]] in [[Israel]], and is a member of the Federation of International Lacrosse and the European Lacrosse Federation.{{cite web|url=http://www.europeanlacrosse.org/about-elf/member-countries|title=Country List|accessdate=1 August 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160809093716/http://www.europeanlacrosse.org/about-elf/member-countries|archivedate=9 August 2016|df=}} It was founded to develop and promote lacrosse within Israel and strives to offer lacrosse to Israelis of all ages.{{cite web |url=http://www.lacrosse.co.il/about-us/ |title=About Us : Israel Lacrosse |accessdate=27 December 2012}} Israel Lacrosse was founded in 2010 by Scott Neiss who previously served as an Executive for the [[National Lacrosse League]], along with [[William Beroza]] and Howard Borkan.[http://filacrosse.com/israel-lacrosse-granted-fil-membership/ Israel Lacrosse Granted FIL Membership] It was officially recognized by the [[Federation of International Lacrosse]] in April 2011.[http://www.atlantic10.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=31600&ATCLID=208912631 ROSEN TABBED ASSOCIATE HEAD COACH FOR ISRAEL LACROSSE NATIONAL TEAM] Israel Lacrosse COO David Lasday directs grassroots youth lacrosse expansion utilizing the status and influence of National Team players to develop the sport throughout Israel {{Cite news|url=https://filacrosse.com/israel-lacrosse-granted-fil-membership/|title=Israel Lacrosse Granted FIL Membership|work=Federation of International Lacrosse|access-date=2018-01-22|language=en-US}} {{Clear}} ==Israel Premier Lacrosse League== {{main|Israel Premier Lacrosse League}} The '''Israel Premier Lacrosse League''' (IPLL) is the premier lacrosse league in Israel, which debuted in 2015.[http://laxmagazine.com/international/2014-15/news/102214_israel_premier_lacrosse_league_set_for_2015_launch Israel Premier Lacrosse League Set for 2015 Launch] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160822201219/http://laxmagazine.com/international/2014-15/news/102214_israel_premier_lacrosse_league_set_for_2015_launch |date=2016-08-22 }} The league competes during summer months only, in an attempt to attract players from abroad to participate.[http://lacrosse.co.il/ipll-announces-2015-schedule/ IPLL Announces 2015 Schedule] ===Teams=== {{:Israel Premier Lacrosse League}} ===Fields=== There are six stadiums used by the IPLL which are: {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#cccccc;" !Field !City |- | [[Ashdod Sport Club]] || [[Ashdod]] |- | [[New Municipal Stadium]] || [[Ashkelon]] |- | [[Mikha Reisser Field]] || [[Be’er Sheva]] |- | [[Kiryat Gat Synthetic]] || [[Kiryat Gat]] |- | [[Tubruq Field]] || [[Netanya]] |- | [[Wolfson Fields]] || [[Tel Aviv]] |- |} ===2015 season=== The 2015 season was the inaugural season of the IPLL. Barak Netanya LC won the IPLL Championship with a win over Haifa LC, with Bryan Hopper winning the EL AL Player of the Game award.[http://lacrosse.co.il/barak-netanya-claims-ipll-crown/ Barak Netanya claims IPLL crown] A total of 16 games were played, with each team playing eight games. {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#cccccc;" !Pos !Team !GP !W !L |- |align=center| 1 || Barak Netanya LC ||align=center| 8 ||align=center| 6 ||align=center| 2 |- |align=center| 2 || Haifa LC ||align=center| 8 ||align=center| 6 ||align=center| 2 |- |align=center| 3 || Ashkelon LC ||align=center| 8 ||align=center| 3 ||align=center| 5 |- |align=center| 4 || Tel Aviv LC ||align=center| 8 ||align=center| 1 ||align=center| 7 |- |} Source:[https://web.archive.org/web/20151002231716/http://www.israelleague.com/?sp_team=barak-netanya-lc 2015 Standings] ===2016 season=== The 2016 season of the IPLL was their second season. Tel Aviv LC decided to suspend operations for the 2016 season, however [[Ashdod LC]], [[Kiryat Gat LC]], and [[Be'er Sheva LC]] joined the league for the 2016 season. A total of 22 games were played, with each team playing either seven or eight games. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- style="background:#cccccc;" !Rank !Team !GP !W !L !Score !Points |- |1 || Be'er Sheva LC || 7 || 6 || 1 || 68:53 || 6 |- |2 || Haifa LC || 7 || 5 || 2 || 70:26 || 5 |- |3 || Ashkelon LC || 8 || 5 || 3 || 64:63 || 5 |- |4 || Ashdod LC || 7 || 4 || 3 || 52:48 || 4 |- |5 || Barak Netanya LC || 7 || 1 || 6 || 45:75 || 1 |- |6 || Kiryat Gat LC || 8 || 1 || 7 || 44:78 || 1 |- |} Source:[http://lacrosse.co.il/schedule-results/#cmd=group-rank-full-ex Schedule / Results] ===2018 season=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- style="background:#cccccc;" !Rank !Team !GP !W !L !Score !Points |- |1 || Be'er Sheva LC || 7 || 6 || 1 || 77:64 || 6 |- |2 || Ashkelon LC || 7 || 4 || 3 || 72:73 || 4 |- |3 || Haifa LC || 7 || 4 || 3 || 63:58 || 4 |- |4 || Barak Netanya LC || 7 || 4 || 3 || 67:54 || 4 |- |5 || Herzliya LC || 7 || 4 || 3 || 68:61 || 4 |- |6 || Sderot || 7 || 3 || 4 || 59:64 || 3 |- |7 || Ashdod LC || 7 || 2 || 5 || 55:68 || 5 |- |8 || Kiryat Gat LC || 7 || 1 || 6 || 46:65 || 1 |- |} Source:[http://lacrosse.co.il/schedule-results/#cmd=group-rank-full-ex Schedule / Results] ==International competition== Israel has both a [[Israel men's national lacrosse team|men's]] and [[Israel women's national lacrosse team|women's]] national team, which competes at both European and World levels. ===European Lacrosse Championships=== In [[2016 European Lacrosse Championship|2016]], Israel's men's team won the Silver Medal, placing second in a field of 24, England won the gold 7-6 in regulation play. This was Israel's first medal in international play.http://lacrosse.co.il/england-holds-on-to-edge-israel-in-euro-final/ {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- style="background:#cccccc;" !Year !Result |- |{{flagicon|NED}} 2012 || 8th place |- |{{flagicon|HUN}} [[2016 European Lacrosse Championship|2016]] || {{silver02}} |} ===World Lacrosse Championships=== Israel qualified for the Men's [[2014 World Lacrosse Championship]] in [[Denver]],{{cite web |title=Israel qualifies for 2014 World Lacrosse Championship |url=http://www.lacrosse.co.il/2012/08/israel-qualifies-for-2014-world-lacrosse-championship/ |accessdate=24 December 2012}}{{cite web |last=Hudes |first=Sammy |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4275910,00.html |title=Israeli lacrosse team qualifies for world championship |accessdate=26 December 2012}} finishing in 7th place out of 38 nations. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- style="background:#cccccc;" !Year !Result |- |{{Flagicon|USA}} [[2014 World Lacrosse Championship|2014]] || 7th place |} ===Women's European Lacrosse Championships=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- style="background:#cccccc;" !Year !Result |- |{{flagicon|CZE}} [[2015 Women's Lacrosse European Championship|2015]] || 4th place |} ===Women's Lacrosse World Cup=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- style="background:#cccccc;" !Year !Result |- |{{Flagicon|CAN}} [[2013 Women's Lacrosse World Cup|2013]] || 8th place |- |{{Flagicon|ENG}} [[2017 Women's Lacrosse World Cup|2017]] || 6th place |- |} ==Shabbat policy== The ILA has a consistent position of not playing or scheduling games on the [[Shabbat]].{{cite news|last=McGran|first=Kevin|url=https://www.thestar.com/sports/amateur/2013/07/15/womens_lacrosse_team_from_israel_ready_to_forfeit.html|title=Women’s lacrosse team from Israel ready to forfeit World Cup rather than play on Sabbath|accessdate=17 July 2013|location=Toronto|work=The Star|date=15 July 2013}} Israel Lacrosse released a statement saying: “As a new sport to Israel it is imperative . . . we cannot ignore that reasonably large percentage of our nations’ people, our teams’ players and our associations’ members would be offended if we took the field on Shabbat." The organization has stated that the policy is a national identity issue, not a religious issue. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Lacrosse topics}} {{Lacrosse in Israel}} [[Category:Lacrosse by country|Israel]] [[Category:Lacrosse governing bodies in Europe|Israel]] [[Category:Lacrosse in Israel| ]] [[Category:2010 establishments in Israel]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=February 2013}}
[[File:Baraque.JPG|thumb|A table for ''Le Multicolore'']] '''Le multicolore''' is a [[game of chance]] from [[France]] and [[Catalonia]] that features characteristics of both [[roulette]] and [[bagatelle]]. In the game, a ball is rolled into a basin-shaped wheel, which is divided into twenty-five shallow cups. Each cup is assigned one of five colours, with a value ascribed. The game consists in predicting on which colour the ball will rest.
The game is played at several ''cercles de jeu''{{clarify|date=October 2011|reason=What is that supposed to mean? This is the English-language Wikipedia. And this term doesn't exist at the French one: [[:fr:Cercle_de_jeu]] = REDLINK.}} in [[France]], where conventional roulette is not allowed.
==Description and rules== The game is composed of a large [[Billiard table|gaming table]] provided with a circular disc on one of its extremes. This wheel has twenty-five identical cups of five different colours: six red, six green, six yellow, six white and one blue. Of the six cups of identical colour one is numbered 4, three 3 and the last two 2, while the blue cup is numbered 24. The wheel may spin, or be statical.
Surrounding the table there is a layout divided and painted with these five colours, where the players can place their wagers.
To determine the winning colour, a croupier strikes, with a cue stick, an ivory ball into a rail, then the ball runs along the cloth, goes up a ramp and enters the circumference of the wheel. The ball eventually falls into one of 25 cups on the wheel. The odds paid on the winning colour are 2, 3, 4 or 24 to 1, depending on the cup where the ball has fallen.
==Notes== * https://web.archive.org/web/20090503021317/http://www.esj-lille.fr/atelier/js/js2003/P4/g4_ev_1.html
[[Category:Roulette and wheel games]] [[Category:Obstacle billiards]] [[Category:French games]] [[Category:Catalan culture]]

revision.text:
[[Game theory]] studies strategic interaction between individuals in situations called games. Classes of these games have been given names. This is a list of the most commonly studied games ==Explanation of features== Games can have several features, a few of the most common are listed here. *'''Number of players''': Each person who makes a choice in a game or who receives a payoff from the outcome of those choices is a player. *'''Strategies per player''': In a game each player chooses from a set of possible actions, known as pure strategies. If the number is the same for all players, it is listed here. *'''Number of [[pure strategy]] [[Nash equilibria]]''': A Nash equilibrium is a set of strategies which represents mutual [[best response]]s to the other strategies. In other words, if every player is playing their part of a Nash equilibrium, no player has an incentive to unilaterally change his or her strategy. Considering only situations where players play a single strategy without randomizing (a pure strategy) a game can have any number of Nash equilibria. *'''[[Sequential game]]''': A game is sequential if one player performs her/his actions after another player; otherwise, the game is a [[simultaneous game|simultaneous move game]]. *'''[[Perfect information]]''': A game has perfect information if it is a sequential game and every player knows the strategies chosen by the players who preceded them. *'''[[Constant sum]]''': A game is constant sum if the sum of the payoffs to every player are the same for every single set of strategies. In these games one player gains if and only if another player loses. A constant sum game can be converted into a '''[[zero sum]] game''' by subtracting a fixed value from all payoffs, leaving their relative order unchanged. ==List of games== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Game !Players !Strategies
per player !No. of [[pure strategy]]
[[Nash equilibria]] ![[Sequential game|Sequential]] ![[Perfect information|Perfect]]
[[Perfect information|information]] ![[Zero sum]] |- |[[Battle of the sexes (game theory)|Battle of the sexes]] |2 |2 |2 |No |No |No |- |[[Blotto games]] |2 |variable |variable |No |No |Yes |- |[[fair cake-cutting|Cake cutting]] |[[N-player game|''N'']], usually 2 |infinite |variableFor the cake cutting problem, there is a simple solution if the object to be divided is homogenous; one person cuts, the other chooses who gets which piece (continued for each player). With a non-homogenous object, such as a half chocolate/half vanilla cake or a patch of land with a single source of water, the solutions are far more complex. |Yes |Yes |Yes |- |[[Centipede game]] |2 |variable |1 |Yes |Yes |No |- |[[Game of chicken|Chicken]] (aka hawk-dove) |2 |2 |2 |No |No |No |- |[[Commune game]] |3 | | | | |- |[[Coordination game]] |[[N-player game|''N'']] |variable |>2 |No |No |No |- |[[Cournot game]] |2 |infiniteThere may be finite strategies depending on how goods are divisible |1 |No |No |No |- |[[Deadlock (game)|Deadlock]] |2 |2 |1 |No |No |No |- |[[Dictator game]] |2 |infinite |1 |N/ASince the dictator game only involves one player actually choosing a strategy (the other does nothing), it cannot really be classified as sequential or perfect information. |N/A |Yes |- |[[Diner's dilemma]] |[[N-player game|''N'']] |2 |1 |No |No |No |- |[[Dollar auction]] |2 |2 |0 |Yes |Yes |No |- |[[El Farol bar problem|El Farol bar]] |[[N-player game|''N'']] |2 |variable |No |No |No |- |[[Example of a game without a value|Game without a value]] |2 |infinite |0 |No |No |Yes |- |[[Guess 2/3 of the average]] |[[N-player game|''N'']] |infinite |1 |No |No |MaybePotentially zero-sum, provided that the prize is split among all players who make an optimal guess. Otherwise non-zero sum. |- |[[Kuhn poker]] |2 |27 & 64 |0 |Yes |No |Yes |- |[[Matching pennies]] |2 |2 |0 |No |No |Yes |- |[[Nash bargaining game]] |2 |infinite |infinite |No |No |No |- |[[Optional prisoner's dilemma]] |2 |3 |1 |No |No |No |- |[[Peace war game]] |[[N-player game|''N'']] |variable |>2 |Yes |No |No |- |[[Pirate game]] |[[N-player game|''N'']] |infinite |infinite |Yes |Yes |No |- |[[Platonia dilemma]] |[[N-player game|''N'']] |2 |2^''N'' - 1 |No |Yes |No |- |[[Princess and monster game]] |2 |infinite |0 |No |No |Yes |- |[[Prisoner's dilemma]] |2 |2 |1 |No |No |No |- |[[Public_goods_game|Public goods]] |[[N-player game|''N'']] |infinite |1 |No |No |No |- |[[Rock, paper, scissors]] |2 |3 |0 |No |No |Yes |- |[[Screening game]] |2 |variable |variable |Yes |No |No |- |[[Signaling games|Signaling game]] |[[N-player game|''N'']] |variable |variable |Yes |No |No |- |[[Stag hunt]] |2 |2 |2 |No |No |No |- |[[Traveler's dilemma]] |2 |N >> 1 |1 |No |No |No |- |[[Truel]] |3 |1-3 |infinite |Yes |Yes |No |- |[[Trust game]] |2 |infinite |1 |Yes |Yes |No |- |[[Ultimatum game]] |2 |infinite |infinite |Yes |Yes |No |- |[[Volunteer's dilemma]] |[[N-player game|''N'']] |2 |2 |No |No |No |- |[[War of attrition (game)|War of attrition]] |2 |2 |0 |No |No |No |} ==External links== * [http://www.gametheory.net/Dictionary/games/ List of games from gametheory.net] * [http://www.lri.fr/~dragice/gameicons/ A visual index to common 2x2 games] ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== * Arthur, W. Brian “[https://ocw.tudelft.nl/wp-content/uploads/ElFarolArtur1994.pdf Inductive Reasoning and Bounded Rationality]”, ''American Economic Review (Papers and Proceedings)'', 84,406-411, 1994. * Bolton, Katok, Zwick 1998, "Dictator game giving: Rules of fairness versus acts of kindness" ''International Journal of Game Theory'', Volume 27, Number 2 * Gibbons, Robert (1992) A Primer in Game Theory, Harvester Wheatsheaf * Glance, Huberman. (1994) "The dynamics of social dilemmas." ''Scientific American.'' *H. W. Kuhn, Simplified Two-Person Poker; in H. W. Kuhn and A. W. Tucker (editors), Contributions to the Theory of Games, volume 1, pages 97–103, Princeton University Press, 1950. * Martin J. Osborne & [[Ariel Rubinstein]]: A Course in Game Theory (1994). * McKelvey, R. and T. Palfrey (1992) "An experimental study of the centipede game," ''Econometrica'' 60(4), 803-836. * [[John Nash (mathematician)|Nash, John]] (1950) "The Bargaining Problem" Econometrica 18: 155-162. * Ochs, J. and A.E. Roth (1989) "An Experimental Study of Sequential Bargaining" American Economic Review 79: 355-384. *[[Anatol Rapoport|Rapoport, A]]. (1966) The game of chicken, American Behavioral Scientist 10: 10-14. *Rasmussen, Eric: Games and Information, 2004 * {{cite web| last=Shor| first=Mikhael| url=http://www.gametheory.net/dictionary/BattleoftheSexes.html| title=Battle of the sexes|publisher=GameTheory.net|accessdate=September 30, 2006}} *{{cite web|last=Shor| first=Mikhael| url=http://www.gametheory.net/dictionary/Games/Deadlock.html|title=Deadlock| publisher=GameTheory.net|accessdate=September 30, 2006}} *{{cite web|last=Shor| first=Mikhael| url=http://www.gametheory.net/dictionary/Games/Matchingpennies.html|title=Matching Pennies| publisher=GameTheory.net|accessdate=September 30, 2006}} * {{cite web| last=Shor| first=Mikhael| url=http://www.gametheory.net/dictionary/Prisonersdilemma.html| title=Prisoner's Dilemma|publisher=GameTheory.net|accessdate=September 30, 2006}} * [[Martin Shubik|Shubik, Martin]] "The Dollar Auction Game: A Paradox in Noncooperative Behavior and Escalation," The ''Journal of Conflict Resolution'', 15, 1, 1971, 109-111. * Sinervo, B., and Lively, C. (1996). "The Rock-Paper-Scissors Game and the evolution of alternative male strategies". Nature Vol.380, pp. 240–243 * Skyrms, Brian. (2003) The stag hunt and Evolution of Social Structure Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. {{Game theory}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Games In Game Theory}} [[Category:Game theory]]

{{pp-30-500|expiry=02:49, 2 December 2018|small=yes}} The following is a '''list of sports/games''', divided by category.
According to the ''World Sports Encyclopedia'' (2003), there are 8,000 indigenous [[sports]] and sporting [[games]].<ref>How many sports are there in the world?] ({{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100723160638/http://www.sportencyclopedia.com/index.php?mod=book |date=July 23, 2010 }}). See {{ISBN|9780760316825}}.</ref>

revision.text:
{{Other people|Michael Leavitt}} [[File:M. B. Leavitt portrait.jpeg|thumb|right|Michael B. Leavitt]]
'''Michael B. Leavitt''' (1843–1935) was an American theater entrepreneur, [[theatre manager|manager]], and [[theatre producer|producer]]. He entered show business as a [[blackface]] [[minstrel show]] singer.<ref>Beasley 192.</ref> By the 1860s, Leavitt had made the leap to management and, following the precedent set by others, was touring [[variety show]] troupes in rural areas, billing them as authentic city entertainment.<ref name="Barth 198">Barth 198.</ref> By 1870, Leavitt had made a name in the theater industry by importing acts to North America from Europe.<ref name="Allen 163">Allen 163.</ref> Leavitt's companies toured both the United States and Mexico; he had a corner on the best theaters in the latter.<ref>Steinmeyer 106.</ref> He sometimes worked in partnership with his brother, [[Abraham Leavitt]].<ref name="Business Man 104">Grau, ''The Business Man'', 104.</ref> Acts he managed include magicians [[Alexander Herrmann]] and [[Harry Kellar]].<ref>Steinmeyer 103.</ref>
In his memoirs, Leavitt claimed to have made several innovations in American show business.<ref>Leavitt</ref> For example, he credited himself with the introduction of [[lithograph]]ic theater posters to the United States in 1872 after he had brought some back from Europe. By the end of the 1870s, lithographic printing had begun to supplant block printing for theater advertising. Leavitt claimed that in the late 1870s, his six to eight touring burlesque companies required $8,000 to $20,000 worth of lithographs posters each season.<ref>Allen 204.</ref> Another of Leavitt's claims was that he was the first to use "all star" as a billing description.<ref>Leavitt 189.</ref> He also claimed that in 1880, he was the first to use the term ''[[vaudeville]]'' to describe a variety show.<ref name="Barth 198"/>
Historians usually cite Leavitt's greatest innovation as the creation of the first touring [[burlesque]] company and of the burlesque style in general.<ref name="Allen 163"/><ref>Wilmeth and Miller 79.</ref> Leavitt had witnessed a European troupe known as Rentz's Circus sometime in the 1870s. He then decided to form an all-woman blackface minstrel troupe, which he named [[Madame Rentz's Female Minstrels]].<ref name="Allen 163"/> The format of its shows, which Leavitt introduced, merged the three-act blackface minstrel show with aspects of [[Lydia Thompson]]'s all-female troupe's show, vaudeville, and [[musical travesty]]. He called the new genre "[[burlesque]]".<ref name="L&W 226">Londré and Watermeier 226.</ref><ref>Shteir 31.</ref> The troupe, later renamed the Rentz-Stantley Company and then the Rentz-Stantley Novelty and Burlesque Company, was a success,<ref name="Business Man 104"/> and it set the standard for burlesque companies through the 1880s and 1890s.<ref name="L&W 226"/>
Leavitt had a taste for [[sensationalism]].<ref name="Allen 163"/> For example, in 1884, he bought the rights to ''[[The Danites]]'', a play by [[McKee Rankin]] that was quite critical of [[the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] (Mormons). Leavitt then decided to stage the play in [[Salt Lake City]], historical center of Mormonism, as a [[publicity stunt]].<ref>Beasley 193.</ref>
Leavitt also handled magicians [[Alexander Herrmann]] and [[Harry Kellar]]. "Whenever I open a new theatre, " Leavitt once said, "I want to insure of large crowds, I will have Herrmann the Great play the date." Herrmann was always a drawing card where ever he played, receiving fifty percent of the gross receipt earning $75,000 a year (about $3 million in today's figures).
Aged 70 in 1914, Leavitt came out of retirement to enter the [[motion picture]] business. He secured the rights to present the film ''[[Sixty Years a Queen]]'' in the Canadian [[Maritimes]]. Despite his advanced age, show business chronicler Robert Grau described Leavitt as "yet as spry and apparently as youthful as he was in his palmy days".<ref>Grau, ''The Theatre of Science'', 302.</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist|3}}
==References== *Allen, Robert C. (1991). ''Horrible Prettiness: Burlesque and American Culture''. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press. {{ISBN|0-8078-4316-4}}. *Barth, Gunther (1980). ''City People: The Rise of Modern City Culture in Nineteenth-Century America''. New York City: Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|0-19-503194-6}}. *Beasley, David (2002). ''McKee Rankin and the Heyday of the American Theater''. Waterloo, Ontario: Wilfrid Laurier University Press. {{ISBN|0-88920-390-3}}. *Grau Robert (1910). ''The Business Man in the Amusement World: A Volume of Progress in the Field of the Theatre''. New York City: Broadway Publishing Company. *Grau, Robert (1914). ''The Theatre of Science: A Volume of Progress and Achievement in the Motion Picture Industry''. New York City: Broadway Publishing Company. *Leavitt, Michael Bennett (1912). ''Fifty Years in Theatrical Management''. New York City: Broadway Publishing Company. *Londré, Felicia Hardison, and Daniel J. Watermeier (1998). ''The History of North American Theater: The United States, Canada, and Mexico: From Pre-Columbian Times to the Present''. New York City: The Continuum International Publishing Group Inc. {{ISBN|0-8264-1233-5}}. *Shteir, Rachel (2004). ''Striptease: The Untold History of the Girlie Show''. New York City: Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|0-19-512750-1}}. *Steinmeyer, Jim (2005). ''The Glorious Deception: The Double Life of William Robinson, aka Chung Ling Soo the "Marvelous Chinese Conjurer"''. New York City: Carroll & Graf. {{ISBN|0-7867-1770-X}}. *Wilmeth, Don B., and Tice L. Miller (1996). ''Cambridge Guide to American Theatre''. New York City: Cambridge University Press. {{ISBN|0-521-56444-1}}.
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Leavitt, Michael B}} [[Category:1843 births]] [[Category:1935 deaths]] [[Category:American theatre managers and producers]] [[Category:Blackface minstrel managers and producers]] [[Category:Blackface minstrel performers]] [[Category:Vaudeville producers]] [[Category:Critics of Mormonism]]

{{Infobox Radio station | name = Radio Skadar | image = | city = [[Podgorica]] | area = {{flagcountry|Montenegro}} | branding = | slogan = "Uglavnom, čudimo se"
English: "Mostly, we wonder" | airdate = | frequency = 107.9 MHz | format = Alternative music radio | power = | erp = | class = | callsign_meaning = | former_callsigns = | owner = | webcast = | website = http://www.radioskadar.me }} '''Radio Skadar''' is an alternative music radio station in [[Montenegro]].{{cite web |url=http://pgportal.me/adresar/49-radio-stanice/32793-radio-skadar-lake.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-10-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130418121058/http://pgportal.me/adresar/49-radio-stanice/32793-radio-skadar-lake.html |archivedate=2013-04-18 |df= }}http://radiomap.eu/me/podgorica Its headquarters are in the village Beri, on the outskirts of [[Podgorica]]. It is named after [[Lake Skadar]] near the city of Podgorica. Its frequency is 107.9 MHz, and is available locally in the area around [[Podgorica]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {{coord missing|Montenegro}} [[Category:Radio stations in Montenegro]] [[Category:Media in Podgorica]] {{montenegro-media-stub}}

{{short description|2016 film directed by Kriv Stenders}} {{Infobox film | name = Red Dog: True Blue | image = Reddogtrueblueposter.jpg | caption = Theatrical film poster | director = [[Kriv Stenders]] | producer = Bryce Menzies
[[Nelson Woss]] | writer = Daniel Taplitz | starring = [[Jason Isaacs]]
[[Levi Miller]]
[[Bryan Brown]] | music = [[Cezary Skubiszewski]] | cinematography = Geoffrey Hall | editing = [[Rodrigo Balart]]
[[Jill Bilcock]] | studio = Woss Group Film Productions
[[Screen Australia]]
[[ScreenWest]] | distributor = [[Village Roadshow|Roadshow Film Distributors]] | released = 26 December 2016 | runtime = 88 minutes | country = Australia | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''Red Dog: True Blue''''' is a 2016 [[Cinema of Australia|Australian]] [[Children's film|family]] [[comedy film]] directed by [[Kriv Stenders]], written by Daniel Taplitz and starring [[Jason Isaacs]], [[Levi Miller]] and [[Bryan Brown]]. It is a prequel to the 2011 film ''[[Red Dog (film)|Red Dog]]'', detailing the early days of the [[Red Dog (Pilbara)|Red Dog, the Pilbara Wanderer]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-05-30/sequel-to-hit-wa-film-red-dog-in-the-works-in-pilbara/5489596|title=Red Dog: Blue Dog film to tell early life of WA's most famous canine|date=30 May 2014|publisher=|via=ABC}} ==Premise== An iconic Australian story of family, friendship and adventure, between a young boy and a scrappy one-of-a-kind dog that would grow up to become an Australian legend.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3567194/|title=Red Dog: True Blue|date=26 December 2016|publisher=|via=IMDb}} ==Cast== *Phoenix as [[Red Dog (Pilbara)|Red Dog]]. He was played in the first film by [[Koko (dog)|Koko]], but was replaced after his death and the film is dedicated to his memory.{{Cite web |url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/movies/red-dog-true-blue-review-marketing-paw-prints-all-over-underwhelming-prequel-20161220-gtfg1b.html |title=Red Dog: True Blue review: marketing paw prints all over underwhelming prequel|date=21 December 2016|publisher=|via=Sydney Morning Herald}} *[[Levi Miller]] as Mick *[[Jason Isaacs]] as Michael Carter (grown up Mick) *[[Bryan Brown]] as Grandpa *Calen Tassone as Taylor Pete (young jackaroo) *Hanna Mangan-Lawrence as Betty *[[Thomas Cocquerel]] as Stemple (helicopter pilot) *Kee Chan as Jimmy Umbrella *[[Steve Le Marquand]] as Little John *[[Justine Clarke]] as Diane Carter (present-day wife & mother) *Zen McGrath as Theo Carter (present-day son) ==Production== Filming began early in 2015 and was released on [[Boxing Day]] in 2016.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3567194/combined|title=Red Dog: True Blue|date=26 December 2016|publisher=|via=IMDb}} ==Reception== ''Red Dog: True Blue'' currently holds a 100% approval rating on [[Rotten Tomatoes]].https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/771445490/ The film grossed $5,218,716 at the Australian box office, a quarter of the original film's takings.http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/intl/?page=&wk=2017W3&id=_fREDDOGTRUEBLUE01 ===Accolades=== Geoffrey Hall was nominated for [[AACTA Award for Best Cinematography|Best Cinematography]] at the [[7th AACTA Awards]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *''[http://www.reddogtruebluemovie.com.au/?ref_=nv_sr_1 Red Dog: True Blue]'' official site *''[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3567194/?ref_=nv_sr_1 Red Dog: True Blue]'' at [[Internet Movie Database]] *''[https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/771445490 Red Dog: True Blue]'' at [[Rotten Tomatoes]] {{Kriv Stenders}} [[Category:2016 films]] [[Category:Australian films]] [[Category:Films scored by Cezary Skubiszewski]] [[Category:Films directed by Kriv Stenders]] [[Category:Films about dogs]] [[Category:Prequel films]] [[Category:Films set in 1969]] [[Category:Films set in 2011]] [[Category:Films set in Western Australia]]

{{Infobox video game| | image = Speed freaks pal cover.jpg | caption = PAL version cover art | developer = [[Funcom|Funcom Dublin Ltd.]] | publisher = [[Sony Computer Entertainment]] | designer = | released = {{vgrelease|EU|September 15, 1999<ref>{{cite web|url=http://psxdatacenter.com/games/P/S/SCES-01763.html|title=Speed Freaks|work=PSX Data Center}}</ref>}}{{vgrelease|NA|March 31, 2000<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uk.psx.ign.com/articles/133/133364p1.html|title=Speed Punks|work=IGN|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090203121829/http://uk.psx.ign.com/articles/133/133364p1.html|archivedate=2009-02-03|df=}}</ref>}} | genre = [[Racing video game|Racing]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] | platforms = [[PlayStation (console)|PlayStation]] }} '''''Speed Freaks''''' ('''''Speed Punks''''' in North America), is a [[racing video game]] for the [[PlayStation (console)|PlayStation]] for up to two players (four with a multi-tap for PlayStation).
The game involves racing around a variety of tracks while using several weapons; including items that make the racer's speed increase, missiles, and slime. The game was developed by [[Funcom]] and released in Europe in September 15, 1999 and in North America on March 31, 2000.
==Gameplay== [[File:Speed Freaks PSX Screenshot.png|thumb|Single player Tournament mode. The green cubes are the pick-up icons and the purple hexagons are speed boost tokens.]] Speed Freaks is a kart racing game featuring several single and multiplayer modes. During the game, players take control of one of nine characters and drive karts around tracks with various themes. During a race, the player's viewpoint is from behind his or her kart. The goal of the game is to either finish a race ahead of other racers, who are [[Artificial intelligence (video games)|controlled by the computer]] and other players, or complete a circuit in the fastest time.
Icons marked with question marks are arrayed on the race tracks; they give weapons (pick-ups) to a player's kart if the vehicle passes over them. Pick-ups, such as missiles and slime, allow racers to hit others with the objects, causing them to spin and lose control. A kart that obtains the stealth mode pick-up is temporarily invulnerable to attack. Lines of speed boost tokens are found on the tracks. By running through these tokens, a kart collects them and fills cells on its speed boost bar. The player can use accumulated speed boost to increase speed at a faster rate than under normal acceleration.
===Modes===
''Speed Freaks'' has three single player modes, Tournament, Single Race and Time attack. In Tournament one player races against five computer-controlled characters in a series of four races called leagues. There are three leagues available, titled Easy, Medium and Hard. Initially only the Easy league is available, by finishing this league, the Medium league is unlocked, which in turn unlocks the Hard league when finished. In order to continue through a league a position of third or higher must be achieved in each race. If a player finishes in fourth to sixth position, the race must be retry – at the cost of one of a limited number of retries – until a placing of third or above is achieved. Points are accrued by finishing in the top three positions in a race; first to third place receive ten, seven and five points. Computer controlled characters are also awarded three points for fourth place and one point for fifth place. The racer with the highest number of points after all four races have been completed wins the league. winning all of the races in a league unlocks one of Three Challenges. In each challenge a player races against one computer-controlled character in a single race, where if the player wins the race, their opponent becomes a playable character. In single race mode, players compete against five computer-controlled characters at a track of the players' choosing from those that are present in Tournament mode. In time attack mode, players race against the clock through the same tracks that are present in Tournament mode, attempting to set the fastest time possible.
''Speed Freaks'' also has two multiplayer modes; Vs. and Multiplayer. In Vs. mode two players race against each other either in a single race or through a league, on the same tracks as are present in the Tournament mode, with the screen split in half. In Multiplayer mode three or four players race against each other, on one of 12 additional tracks. The tracks featured in this mode have lower detail than those in single player and Vs. mode.<ref name="powerpreview" /> This game mode requires the [[Multitap]] peripheral in order for four controllers to be connected to the PlayStation.
===Characters===
''Speed Freaks'' features nine original characters from which the player can choose to compete as or against. Six characters are available immediately at the start of the game and three further characters can be unlocked by beating them in a challenge. Each character's kart has different capabilities with differing levels of top speed, acceleration and handling.
== Development == ''Speed Freaks'' was produced by Padraig Crowley and designed and developed by the SD Team at Funcom Dublin in Ireland.<ref name="manualcredits">{{cite book |title=Speed Freaks Manual |publisher=Sony Computer Entertainment Europe |article=Credits |page=28}}</ref> The game took over two years to develop. Working titles used included "Project SDR" and "Wheelnuts".<ref name="powerpreview">{{cite news| title = Speed Freaks (Preview) | work = Playstation Power Issue 40 | pages = 32–35 | publisher = Future Publishing|date=June 1999}}</ref>
The game was released in North America under the title ''Speed Punks''. Sony acquired the rights to publish the game in the region as early as the summer of 1999, but held back as to avoid competing with ''[[Crash Team Racing]]''.<ref>{{cite web | author=IGN staff | date=April 13, 2000 | title=Speed Punks | url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2000/04/14/speed-punks-2 | publisher=[[IGN]] | accessdate=December 14, 2013}}</ref>
"[[Travelling Without Moving]]" by [[Jamiroquai]] is used in the introduction video of this videogame. Other music within the game is by Martin Schioler.<ref name="manualcredits" />
==Reception== The game received mostly positive reviews. [[IGN]] gave it a 9/10.<ref>{{cite web | author=Bishop, Sam | date=April 19, 2000 | title=Speed Punks | url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2000/04/20/speed-punks | publisher=[[IGN]] | accessdate=December 14, 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Funcom}}

page.title: The First Collection of Criticism by a Living Female Rock Critic

revision.comment: Adding image
revision.text:
{{italics title}} {{Infobox book | italic title = <!--(see above)--> | name = The First Collection of Criticism by a Living Female Rock Critic | image = The First Collection of Criticism by a Living Female Rock Critic.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | author = [[Jessica Hopper]] | audio_read_by = | title_orig = | orig_lang_code = | title_working = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = | language = English | series = | release_number = | subject = Music | genre = | set_in = | publisher = [[Featherproof Books|Featherproof]] | publisher2 = | pub_date = May 12, 2015 | english_pub_date = | published = | media_type = | pages = 201 | awards = | isbn = 978-0983186335 | isbn_note = | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | native_wikisource = | wikisource = | notes = | exclude_cover = | website = ''[http://www.featherproof.com/catalog/ebook-first-collection-of-criticism-by-a-living-female-rock-critic The First Collection of Criticism by a Living Female Rock Critic]'' }} '''''The First Collection of Criticism by a Living Female Rock Critic''''' is a 2015 essay collection by music critic [[Jessica Hopper]].<ref name="Voice">{{cite news|last1=Potts|first1=Dianca|title=Jessica Hopper Compiles Greatest Hits for Her First Collection of Rock Criticism|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/music/jessica-hopper-compiles-greatest-hits-for-her-first-collection-of-rock-criticism-6628420|accessdate=11 March 2016|work=Village Voice|date=May 26, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Time">{{cite news|last1=Berman|first1=Eliza|title=Jessica Hopper: Stop Telling Girls the Way They Listen to Music Is Wrong|url=http://time.com/3847346/jessica-hopper-music-critic/|accessdate=11 March 2016|work=Time Magazine|date=May 12, 2015}}</ref>
==Development and publication== The idea of collecting her columns into a book had been suggested to Hopper some years earlier by [[Akashic Books|Akashic]] publisher [[Johnny Temple (bassist)|Johnny Temple]]; the project ultimately came to fruition when her friend, musician [[Tim Kinsella]], became head of [[Featherproof Books]] in 2014 and asked Hopper to make a book of her criticism his first project with the publishing house.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.salon.com/2015/05/12/rock_critic_jessica_hopper_on_being_young_female_and_unapologetic_about_her_place_in_the_canon_if_i_dont_fit_in_it_then_who_the_fk_does/|title=Rock critic Jessica Hopper on being young, female and unapologetic about her place in the canon: "If I don’t fit in it, then who the f**k does?"|date=May 12, 2015|work=Salon|last1=Zaleski|first1=Annie|accessdate=7 July 2017}}</ref>
[[File:Jessica Hopper.jpg|thumb|left|Jessica Hopper in 2015]] Featherproof published the book on May 12, 2015.
==Content== The book contains 42 pieces of Hopper's work, organized thematically into eight chapters.<ref name="Snapes Guardian" /> They are drawn from reviews, interviews, and essays in a range of publications from mainstream to fanzines.
==Reception== ''The First Collection'''s popularity prompted three print runs from presales alone.<ref name="Snapes Guardian">{{cite news|last1=Snapes|first1=Laura|title=Jessica Hopper: 'I can't mute my moral self when listening to a record'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/may/14/jessica-hopper-new-book-macho-world-of-rock-writing|accessdate=11 March 2016|work=The Guardian|date=May 14, 2015}}</ref>
Reviewing the book in the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', Kathleen Rooney compared Hopper to critics like [[Pauline Kael]] and [[Susan Sontag]], saying "Every piece...is powerfully written, wittily observed and unafraid to argue. Taken individually...and as a whole, they make an airtight case for why the professional critic still matters, and why it is a thrill to spend time in the presence of someone whose job it is to care so much and so intelligently."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/lifestyles/books/ct-prj-first-collection-rock-criticism-jessica-hopper-20150514-story.html|title=Review: 'The First Collection of Criticism by a Living Female Rock Critic' by Jessica Hopper|last=Rooney|first=Kathleen|date=May 14, 2015|work=Chicago Tribune|access-date=2017-07-07|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref> ''[[New York Times]]'' book critic [[Dwight Garner (critic)|Dwight Garner]] described ''The First Collection'' as "by turns loose and warm and finicky and outraged, and its best pieces are more observant than 94 percent of the first novels that have come my way this year."<ref name="New York Times">{{cite news|last1=Garner|first1=Dwight|title=Review: Jessica Hopper Looks Beyond the Boys and Their Bands in a New Book|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/18/books/review-jessica-hopper-looks-beyond-the-boys-and-their-bands-in-a-new-book.html|accessdate=11 March 2016|work=New York Times|date=June 17, 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * ''[http://www.featherproof.com/catalog/ebook-first-collection-of-criticism-by-a-living-female-rock-critic The First Collection of Criticism by a Living Female Rock Critic]'' at [[Featherproof Books]] {{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:First Collection of Criticism by a Living Female Rock Critic}} [[Category:2015 books]] [[Category:Music books]]

page.title: The Girl with the Whooping Cough

revision.comment: added [[Category:Plays by Stanislaus Stange]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox play | name = The Girl with the Whooping Cough | image = Girl with Whooping Cough poster.jpg | image_alt = Color poster with three images of a woman posing. Text around the images reads "A.H. Woods presents Valeska Suratt in the swift, smart and saucy play, The Girl with the Whooping Cough, the latest Parisian sensation by Stanislaus Stange". | caption = Poster promoting the play on Broadway | writer = [[Stanislaus Stange]] | characters = | setting = | premiere = {{Start date|1910|04|25}} | place = [[Olympia Theatre (New York City)|New York Theatre]] | orig_lang = English | genre = [[Farce]] }}
'''''The Girl with the Whooping Cough''''' is a [[Play (theatre)|play]] written by [[Stanislaus Stange]] in 1910. Adapted from a French farce, the show featured [[dialogue]] that was condemned as indecent by many contemporary reviewers. The play's appearance on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] was suppressed when [[New York City]] officials threatened not to renew the operating license of the theater.
==Plot== The story follows the misbehaviors of Regina ([[Valeska Suratt]]) as she passes [[whooping cough]] to the numerous men she kisses. In the final act, her amours land her in divorce court, where she performs a dance routine borrowed from Suratt's [[vaudeville]] act.<ref name="boardman">{{cite book |first=Gerald |last=Bordman |title=American Theatre: A Chronicle of Comedy and Drama, 1869-1914 |location=New York |publisher=Oxford University Press |year=1994 |isbn=0-19-503764-2 |page=672}}</ref><ref name="nytreview">{{cite news |title=Whooping Cough Girl Stupid |work=The New York Times |date=April 26, 1910 |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1910/04/26/104931199.pdf |accessdate=August 7, 2013}}</ref>
==Broadway production and suppression== After early performances in [[Trenton, New Jersey]],<ref name="trenton">{{cite news |title=Mayor Closes N.Y. Theater |work=Trenton True American |date=May 11, 1910 |page=1 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=eXRFAAAAIBAJ&sjid=l7wMAAAAIBAJ&pg=1464,1425323&dq=girl-with-the-whooping-cough&hl=en |accessdate=August 7, 2013}}</ref> producer [[Albert H. Woods|Al Woods]] brought the play to [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]], with sultry vaudeville actress [[Valeska Suratt]] in the lead role. It opened at the [[Olympia Theatre (New York City)|New York Theatre]] on April 25, 1910. Trenton police had attended a rehearsal and declared the play fit for performance after some mild [[censorship]],<ref>{{cite news |title=Police Censor Today's Show |work=Trenton True American |date=March 26, 1910 |page=1 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2mdgAAAAIBAJ&sjid=DHINAAAAIBAJ&pg=3088,3937067 |accessdate=August 7, 2013}}</ref> but when it came to New York, Mayor [[William Jay Gaynor]] viewed it less favorably. Hearing rumors about the play's content, he reviewed a script beforehand and found nothing objectionable in it. When the production went live, he received complaints that made him suspect he had not been given an accurate script. He decided to send [[stenographers]] to take notes on its content. They reported back that the actors had "interpolated" salacious elements into the performance.<ref name="blue">{{cite book |title=Blue Vaudeville: Sex, Morals and the Mass Marketing of Amusement, 1895-1915 |first=Andrew L. |last=Erdman |publisher=McFarland |location=Jefferson, North Carolina |year=2004 |isbn=0-7864-1827-3 |page=118}}</ref>
Based on this evidence, Gaynor asked [[New York City Police Commissioner]] William F. Baker to suppress the play. On May 6, 1910, Baker contacted the theater's management company, [[Klaw & Erlanger]]. He threatened that if the play was not stopped, he would refuse to renew the theater's operating license, which expired at the end of April. [[Abraham L. Erlanger]] promised to cancel the show, but Woods did not agree. After unsatisfactory meetings with Baker and Gaynor, Woods went to the [[New York Supreme Court]] on May 9, 1910, to get an [[injunction]] preventing the police from closing down the play. The judge gave Woods the order he requested, but while it prevented the authorities from interfering with the show directly, it did not compel them to renew the license for the theater. Left with no home for his production, Woods was forced to shut it down.<ref name="mayor">{{cite news |title=Mayor Cuts Off an Indecent Play |work=The New York Times |date=May 11, 1910 |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1910/05/11/104933700.pdf |accessdate=August 7, 2013}}</ref>
Notwithstanding the objections from Woods, Gaynor's actions garnered a positive response from the press. A column in ''[[The New York Times]]'' said his actions were guided by "common sense and good taste".<ref>{{cite news |title=Topics of the Week: New York's Censor |work=The New York Times |date=May 14, 1910 |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1910/05/14/104934647.pdf |accessdate=August 7, 2013}}</ref> When the show headed to other cities, Gaynor threatened to write other mayors to warn them against it.<ref>{{cite news |title=Valeska Suratt, Actress Who Has Been Suppressed |work=The Day |date=May 12, 1910 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=CPQgAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hXQFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4130,1040946 |accessdate=August 7, 2013}}</ref>
==Reception== The play was "unmercifully damned by the critics", according to theater scholar [[Gerald Bordman]].<ref name="boardman" /> The ''Trenton True American'' described the performances there as "disgustingly vulgar".<ref name="trenton" /> A brief review of the Broadway opening from ''[[The New York Times]]'' called it "stupid", although the reviewer found some humor in the performance of supporting player Dallas Welford.<ref name="nytreview" /> Drama critic [[George Jean Nathan]] called it "nauseating and ... disgusting in its futile efforts to be risqué".<ref>{{cite journal |first=George Jean |last=Nathan |authorlink=George Jean Nathan |title=The Dramatic Valedictory |work=[[The Smart Set]] |volume=31 |number=1 |date=May 1910 |page=149}}</ref>
When the play went on the road after being shut down in New York, the ''Philadelphia Times'' declared it "coarse", "vulgar" and not worthy of any "self-respecting person".<ref name="blue" />
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{IBDB title|7155}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Girl with the Whooping Cough, The}} [[Category:1910 plays]] [[Category:Broadway plays]] [[Category:Censorship in the United States]] [[Category:Comedy plays]] [[Category:English-language plays]] [[Category:Plays based on other plays]] [[Category:Censored works]] [[Category:Plays by Stanislaus Stange]]

revision.comment: /* Production */
revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = The Illusionist | image = The_Illusionist_Poster.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Neil Burger]] | producer = {{plainlist| *[[Brian Koppelman]] *David Levien *[[Michael London]] *[[Cathy Schulman]] *[[Bob Yari]] }} | screenplay = Neil Burger | based on = {{Based on|"Eisenheim the Illusionist"|[[Steven Millhauser]]}} | starring = {{plainlist| *[[Edward Norton]] *[[Paul Giamatti]] *[[Jessica Biel]] }} | music = [[Philip Glass]] | cinematography = [[Dick Pope (cinematographer)|Dick Pope]] | editing = [[Naomi Geraghty]] | studio = [[Bob Yari Productions]]
Contagious Entertainment
[[Stillking Films]]{{cite web|title=Norton’s “Illusionist” wraps in Prague|url=http://www.filmcommission.cz/en/nortons-illusionist-wraps-in-prague/|website=www.filmcommission.cz|accessdate=10 February 2018|language=cs}}{{cite web|title=The Illusionist - UPP|url=https://www.upp.cz/film/the-illusionist-3|website=UPP|accessdate=10 February 2018}} | distributor = [[Yari Film Group|Yari Film Group Releasing]]
[[Freestyle Releasing]]{{Cite news|url=http://freestylereleasing.com/the-illusionist/|title=The Illusionist|date=2006-08-19|work=Freestyle Releasing|access-date=2017-04-19|language=en-US}} | released = {{Film date|2006|8|18}} | runtime = 110 minutes | country = United States
Czech Republic{{cite web|title=Iluzionista — Česká televize|url=http://www.ceskatelevize.cz/porady/10154231036-iluzionista/20838145967/|website=Česká televize|accessdate=7 August 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Spáčilová|first1=Mirka|title=Edward Norton potkal Cimrmana|url=http://kultura.zpravy.idnes.cz/edward-norton-potkal-cimrmana-dk5-/filmvideo.aspx?c=A061104_618033_show_recenze_kot|website=iDNES.cz|accessdate=7 August 2016|date=4 November 2006}} | language = English | budget = $16.5 million | gross = $87.8 million }} '''''The Illusionist''''' is a 2006 American [[romance film|romantic]] [[mystery film]] written and directed by [[Neil Burger]] and starring [[Edward Norton]], [[Paul Giamatti]], and [[Jessica Biel]]. It is based loosely on [[Steven Millhauser]]'s short story, "Eisenheim the Illusionist". The film tells the story of Eisenheim, a [[Magic (illusion)|magician]] in turn-of-the-century [[Vienna]], who reunites with his childhood love, a woman far above his social standing. The film also depicts a fictionalized version of the [[Mayerling incident]]. The film premiered at the [[2006 Sundance Film Festival]] and opened the 2006 [[Seattle International Film Festival]]; it was distributed in limited release to theaters on August 18, 2006, and expanded nationwide on September 1. The film was a commercial and critical success. ==Plot== In [[Vienna]], [[Austria-Hungary]], 1889, a magician named Eisenheim is arrested by Chief Inspector Walter Uhl of the Vienna Police during a magic show involving [[necromancy]]. Later, Uhl explains the story of Eisenheim's life to Crown Prince Leopold. Eisenheim was born to a cabinet-maker and became interested in magic after meeting a travelling magician. He also fell in love with Sophie, the [[Duchy of Teschen|Duchess von Teschen]], but the two were forbidden to see each other on account of the former being a peasant. They kept meeting secretly but were caught one day and separated by force. Eisenheim proceeded to study magic by travelling the world, and fifteen years later returned to Vienna to perform. During one performance, he encounters the adult Sophie and learns that she is expected to marry the Crown Prince Leopold, who, it is rumored, is brutal towards women and in the past even murdered one. Eisenheim conducts a private show for the Crown Prince and humiliates him in the course of it. In response, he is banned from performing again in Vienna. Eisenheim asks Sophie to flee with him, but Sophie is afraid that they will be hunted down and executed. Sophie also reveals that the Crown Prince is planning a ''[[coup d'etat]]'' against his elderly father, the Emperor [[Franz Joseph I of Austria|Franz Joseph I]]. At the [[Mayerling]] hunting lodge, Sophie tries to end her engagement with Leopold. He reacts by chasing her into the stables with a sword, in full view of the servants. Sophie's body is discovered the next morning in the [[Vienna Woods]], an unknown man blamed for her assassination. This throws Eisenheim into a deep depression. He eventually buys a theatre and begins a new series of magic shows, this time focusing exclusively on the summoning of dead spirits. Leopold secretly attends one of them, during which Eisenheim summons the spirit of Sophie, who says that someone in the theater is her murderer. Leopold, highly unnerved, orders Uhl to arrest Eisenheim for fraud, but Eisenheim manages to avoid jail by openly confessing to the public that his show is a mere illusion. Eisenheim is threatened that if he summons Sophie in his next performance, he will be arrested and likely imprisoned. Uhl attends the packed performance with dozens of officers, and in spite of the warnings, Eisenheim brings Sophie's spirit to life again. Uhl storms the stage with his officers, but to the shock and horror of the audience, Eisenheim is revealed to be a spirit when Uhl's hand passes through him. Eisenheim then fades away in front of everyone. Uhl reveals to Leopold that he has found evidence - a jewel from Leopold's sword and Sophie's distinctive locket - which could implicate Leopold in Sophie's murder. Uhl has already informed the Emperor and the [[General Staff]] of Leopold's conspiracy to seize the throne. Leopold points a [[revolver]] at Uhl, threatening to kill him, but as officers of the imperial guard of the [[Austro-Hungarian Army]] arrive, Leopold shoots himself in the head. Later, as Uhl leaves the palace, he places Sophie's locket in his pocket. He is now no longer Chief Inspector of Police. As a boy approaches him, he is jostled by a bearded man in a long coat. The boy gives him a package containing Eisenheim's notebook about the Orange Tree trick, which Uhl had been unable to figure out. He asks the boy who it was that gave him the notebook, and the boy replies "Herr Eisenheim." He checks his pocket and realizes the person who jostled him stole the locket. He sees the man and chases after him, but the man boards a train and escapes. Uhl realizes the jostling and the notebook are a message from the illusionist, and begins to rethink recent events. He concludes that Sophie and Eisenheim staged her death so that she could be free of Leopold. Uhl laughs delightedly at the brilliance of their plan. Later, and far away, Sophie and Eisenheim start a new life together in a cabin at the foot of a beautiful mountain. Eisenheim places Sophie's locket in her palm. ==Cast== * [[Edward Norton]] as Eisenheim the Illusionist (born Eduard Abramovich) ** [[Aaron Taylor-Johnson|Aaron Johnson]] as young Eisenheim * [[Paul Giamatti]] as Chief Inspector Walter Uhl * [[Jessica Biel]] as Duchess Sophie von Teschen ** [[Eleanor Tomlinson]] as young Sophie * [[Rufus Sewell]] as Crown Prince Leopold * [[Eddie Marsan]] as Josef Fischer, Eisenheim's manager * [[Jake Wood]] as Jurka ==Production== {{refimprove|section|date=August 2017}} The script was based loosely on "Eisenheim the Illusionist", a [[short story]] by [[Steven Millhauser]] from Millhauser's 1990 collection ''[[The Barnum Museum]]''. Together with ''[[The Prestige (film)|The Prestige]]'' and ''[[Scoop (2006 film)|Scoop]]'', ''The Illusionist'' was one of three films in 2006 to explore the world of [[Magic (illusion)|stage magicians]]. Magic consultancy and technical advice during the production was supplied by [[James Freedman (pickpocket)|James Freedman]], [[Ricky Jay]], Michael Weber and [[Scott Penrose]]. Director [[Neil Burger]] wrote, "Starting in pre-production, James (Freedman) became a major collaborator; brainstorming, designing and refining everything from small sleight of hand tricks to major narrative set pieces. He worked with [[Edward Norton]] preparing him for his stage performances and acted as a hand double in various scenes. His contribution was enormous."{{cite web| url= http://www.magicweek.co.uk/backissues_0250-0299/0292.htm | title= News (Number 292) | date=28 January 2006| publisher=magicweek.co.uk | accessdate=2009-12-25}} [[Aaron Johnson]], who plays the teenage Eduard in the beginning of the film, also learned how to do the ball trick seen in those scenes.{{cite video |people= Screenwriter/director [[Neil Burger]] |date= |title= [[Audio commentary]] for ''The Illusionist'' |medium= DVD |publisher= |accessdate = |time=?{{When|date=December 2010}} |id= |isbn= |oclc= |quote= |ref= }} The original story, on which the movie is based, does not include the artifice of the [[protagonist]] framing the Archduke for murder. Although the film is set in [[Austria]], it was filmed mostly in the [[Czech Republic]]. The city of [[Vienna]] is represented in the film by [[Tábor]] and [[Prague]], while the scenes set in Eisenheim's childhood village were shot in [[Český Krumlov]]. The Crown Prince's castle is actually the historical fortress of [[Konopiště]] (located near [[Benešov]]), formerly the home of [[Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria]]. The front gates of Leopold's Vienna palace (the [[Hofburg]]) were actually the front gates of [[Prague Castle]]. All other shots were at [[Barrandov Studios]] in Prague. ==Reception== As of June 29, 2008 the film has earned worldwide box office receipts of $87,892,388, including $39,868,642 in the United States, exceeding its reported $16.5 million budget.{{mojo title|id=illusionist}}. Retrieved 2009-12-25. In the first five months after it was released on DVD in January 2007, the film earned $35.99 million in rental revenue.[http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=homevideo&id=illusionist.htm The Illusionist (2006) - DVD / Home Video Rentals] from [[Box Office Mojo]]. Retrieved 2009-12-25. ''The Illusionist'' received mostly positive reviews. [[Rotten Tomatoes]] classified it as 73% "certified fresh" with 190 reviews (as of March 4, 2018).{{rotten-tomatoes|id=illusionist|title=The Illusionist}} [[Jonathan Rosenbaum]]'s review in ''The Chicago Reader'' praised Paul Giamatti's performance of "a character who feels sympathy for the magician but owes allegiance to Leopold and is therefore divided and compromised ... Giamatti's performance is subtle, expressive, and richly nuanced."[http://www.chicagoreader.com/features/stories/moviereviews/060818/ Chicago Reader: Movie Reviews] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061019042454/http://www.chicagoreader.com/features/stories/moviereviews/060818/ |date=2006-10-19 }} [[Stephen Holden]], in his review for ''[[The New York Times]]'', praised Edward Norton's role, which, according to him, "perfectly fits his disturbing inscrutability".[http://movies2.nytimes.com/2006/08/18/movies/18illu.html?ref=movies The Illusionist - Movie - Review] from ''[[The New York Times]]'' ''Variety'' wrote that [[Jessica Biel]] "is entirely stunning enough to fight to the death over".[http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117929353.html?categoryId=31&cs=1 ''The Illusionist'' Review from Sundance] from ''Variety'' magazine Director of Photography [[Dick Pope (cinematographer)|Dick Pope]] earned a nomination for the [[Academy Award for Best Cinematography]], losing at the [[79th Academy Awards]] to [[Guillermo Navarro]], cinematographer for ''[[Pan's Labyrinth]]''. ==Soundtrack== The soundtrack for the film was composed by [[Philip Glass]] and was released on 15 August 2006. ===Track listing=== *"The Illusionist" – 2:24 *"Do You Know Me" – 2:48 *"Chance Encounter" – 3:23 *"The Locket" – 2:54 *"The Orange Tree" – 1:47 *"The Mirror" – 1:27 *"Wish I Would See You Again" – 1:26 *"The Sword" – 0:36 *"Meeting in the Carriage" – 1:09 *"Sophie" – 2:50 *"The Secret Plot" – 2:53 *"Sophie's Ride to the Castle" – 2:05 *"The Accident" – 1:30 *"The New Theater" – 1:39 *"Frankel Appears" – 3:26 *"A Shout from the Crowd" – 2:02 *"Eisenheim Disappears" – 2:07 *"The Search" – 3:00 *"The Missing Gem" –3:03 *"The Chase" –4:11 *"Life in the Mountains"-4:31 ==TV show== On October 14, 2014, it was announced that [[The CW]] was developing a TV series based on the film.{{cite web|last1=Andreeva|first1=Nellie|title=‘The Illusionist’ Series Based On Movie In Works At The CW|url=http://deadline.com/2014/10/the-illusionist-tv-series-cw-851451/|website=Deadline.com|accessdate=7 December 2015}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{wikiquote|The Illusionist}} {{italic title}} {{Infobox video game | collapsible = | state = | title = The Impossible Game | image = The Impossible Game logo.jpg | caption = ''The Impossible Game'' logo | developer = [[Grip Games]] | publisher = FlukeDude | series = | engine = | platforms = Xbox 360, PlayStation 3, PSP, Android, iOS, Nokia, PC | released = Xbox 360 (2009),
Amazon, Android, iOS, PSP, PS3 (2011), [[Windows]] (2014) | genre = [[Arcade game|Arcade]], [[Platform game|platformer]] | modes = }} '''''The Impossible Game''''' is a 2009 one-button platformer game developed by Grip Games and published by FlukeDude. == Gameplay == [[File: The Impossible Game screenshot.jpg|200px|thumbnail|Screenshot of the Fire Aura level, in the Android version of the game]] The objective of the game is to guide a cube over spikes and pits. There are 5 levels in the game (2 in iOS and Android normal versions), four of which with original music. A Practice Mode where flags (checkpoints) can be placed, is available. Each time a level is beaten, a medal is unlocked. === Level editor === On the PC version of the game, there is a level editor available, which players can use to make their own levels, and custom music may be used. == Reception == {{Video game reviews | GR = (X360) 60%
(iOS) 67%
(PSP) 87%
(PC) 67% | MC = (PC) 64 | EuroG= 6/10 }} The Impossible Game received generally mixed reviews. On [[Metacritic]], the PC version received an aggregated score of 64.{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/the-impossible-game |title=The Impossible Game PC |website=Metacritic |access-date=10 April 2015}} On [[GameRankings]], it received 60% on Xbox 360,{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/xbox360/980385-the-impossible-game/index.html |title=The Impossible Game for Xbox 360 |website=GameRankings |access-date=10 April 2015}} 67% on iOS,{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/iphone/696022-the-impossible-game/index.html |title=The Impossible Game for iOS (iPhone/iPad) |website=GameRankings |access-date=6 August 2015}} 87% on PSP,{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/psp/640855-the-impossible-game/index.html |title=The Impossible Game for PSP |website=GameRankings |access-date=10 April 2015}} and 67% on PC.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/pc/794175-the-impossible-game/index.html |title=The Impossible Game for PC |website=GameRankings |access-date=10 April 2015}} [[Eurogamer]] gave the Xbox 360 version a 6/10, stating that "it's monumentally frustrating, but also bafflingly addictive as you continually try to make precious progress".{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/download-games-roundup-2nd-april-2010?page=2 |title=Download Games Roundup • Page 2 |website=Eurogamer |access-date=10 April 2015}} == See Also == *[[Geometry Dash]], a similar game developed by RobtopGames == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://flukedude.com/theimpossiblegame/}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Impossible Game}} [[Category:Platform games]] [[Category:2009 video games]] [[Category:Android (operating system) games]] [[Category:IOS games]] [[Category:PlayStation 3 games]] [[Category:PlayStation Network games]] [[Category:PlayStation Portable games]] [[Category:Video games developed in the Czech Republic]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Xbox 360 Live Arcade games]]
